newsitem.title: USA: Talks start on Korean peace proposals. [CORRECTED 16:41 GMT]
newsitem.headline: Talks start on Korean peace proposals. [CORRECTED 16:41 GMT]

text.p: South Korean, North Korean and U.S. officials met for the first time on Wednesday to discuss proposals for international talks on ending the technical state of war on the Korean peninsula.

"The meeting started with the members of the delegations exchanging small talk and pleasantries," said New York Foreign Press Centre spokesman Kenneth Bailes, who was present at the beginning of the meeting.

The high-level gathering resulted from a proposal to North Korea last April by President Bill Clinton and South Korean President Kim Young-sam for four-way talks, including China, to work out a peace agreement to replace the armistice that ended the 1950-53 Korean War.
Wednesday's meeting in New York was convened at the request of North Korea, which wanted more information on Washington and Seoul's proposals for such talks, U.S. officials said.
They said the meeting, described by the U.S. State Department as a "joint briefing," would be followed on Friday by talks in New York between U.S. and North Korean officials.
